messageBody:
On Fri, May 15, 2009 at 3:06 PM, Miles Parker <milesparker@...> wrote:
>>
>> > day. But it doesn't look like I can use inheirit from Suite or Parent
>> > Runner for example because they both are looking for a class.
>>
>> You can actually give pass Suite a null for the parent class, and then
>> a list of subclasses.
>
> Right, but given below then the subclasses have to be known at
> discovery time, right? Or can we simply have the class *name* at that
> time? IOTW, appropos below, do all classes also have to be loaded at
> discovery time, or are we simply building an arbitrary tree for which
> the actual test classes can be loaded and instantiated at runtime?

The API for Runner is

getDescription()
run()

JUnit's built-in Suite runner does indeed load the referenced classes
in the getDescription() phase. If you write your own custom runner,
you have total control over what computation to do in each phase.

>
>> > But the trick
>> > of course is that needs to be deferred until test run-time.
>>
>> Does the test discovery step _need_ to happen inside a test computation? Why?
>>
>> I have a feeling we have a mismatch of assumptions.
>
> Yes, or expectations. My dilemma is that it doesn't make sense for me
> to go through trying to put this kind of harness together without
> knowing wether it is possible, but it's a lot to expect that someone
> who would actually know wether it was possible would want to take the
> time to understand what I'm trying to do. :D So the short answer is
> yes, I need or really really want this and I've thought it through
> quite a bit. The long answer...
>
> In a way JUnit's raison d'Ãªtre is the philosophy that one should
> specify *a priori* and statically what is expected and then check that
> that indeed happens, right? So a lot of the architecture quite
> understandably carries that simplifying assumption. BUt.. it begins to
> get more confused as we add leverage through model-driven / generative
> techniques. I'm working at a bit of a meta-level here -- there are
> tests that ensure things like wether the classes are actually
> generated correctly and doing so with an arbitrary set of targets; but
> we are *also* actually generating the test code that exercises that
> target code. There is an aspect to the code-gen process that gets
> switched on and adds test annotations, potentially in-line asserts and
> so on either by specializing the target code generated classes or by
> creating proxies. I want the discovery of test methods so that we
> ensure coverage for newly generated model behaviors and to ease
> maintenance.

Why can't all of this happen during getDescription()?

David Saff
